On my own time I prefer to use python for web work and C#/Unity for game dev, but I'm a big proponent of using the right tools for the job. Ideally looking for a role doing something socially conscious.* At my last job I led a team and helped build a Windows desktop app that pulled data from native node modules and added overlays to games. I also started learning Rust from working with other engineers on the native node modules.* On the side I'm learning more Rust and also building https://bigplaylist.club/ - a small site (mostly for my personal use) that lets you create music playlists from multiple streaming sources (youtube, soundcloud, bandcamp, etc.)

description: codeforafrica 16 days ago | prev | next [–]Contract, part-time employmentContact: Email: see profile or http://codingforafrica.at/Like this Ask HN: Recommend employers with positive social impact [https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=31518945], I am looking for similar work. I am a European software developer who has lived and worked on four continents. Now it's time to move on and so i am in the process to relocate to Africa.While i could find a job elsewhere i believe that the experience living in an area where my work is going to have an impact gives me a better understanding of the needs of the location i am serving. Whether it is through direct contact with clients and users or just by being part of a local community and learning about the reality of living there.I have more than a decade of experience running a company, doing software development, support and training and mentoring adults and students, as well as working on educational projects, and i am willing to take on a mixture of roles as needed to support a project.I am also open to work for a company anywhere as long as the work can be done fully remote from Africa.In addition, i want to use part of my income to hire local interns and junior developers and train them in order to pass on my experience. If you want to support this, i would love to work with you. Also if you are interested in hiring African developers yourself.

technologies: JavaScript (some TypeScript but not extensive), React, Vue, Node, MongoDB, Deno, Ruby, Rails
description: chaosharmonic 16 days ago | prev | next [–]Email and other contact info can be found on my website: bhmt.devI'm a full-stack Web dev with about 2yrs in production environments, as well as a scattering of freelance work/side projects and >5yrs prior experience running support desks in various capacities (including one that also involved some Scrum Master work). I'm primarily self-taught, in ways that are fueled by -- in varying parts -- a DIY habit, a distaste or depending on cloud vendors, troubleshooting dives, and an urge to automate out tasks I (or other people) don't want to do. (That last one is where I'd say my best work tends to be.) I enjoy excuses to expand on this, and have a few other areas of curiosity beyond the ones I'd actually call an expertise, ranging from DevOps to cybersecurity to ML.Longer-term, I really want to work on open-source and/or Web infrastructure (examples of orgs that catch my attention include Mozilla, GitLab, and Element), but in the immediate one I don't have strong opinions about mission fit right now, as my core focus after a particularly traumatizing previous workplace is to find someplace that operates differently.So much so that I've been on a Web scraping rabbit hole for the last several months, building a bot to doomscroll job boards for me so that I have an escape hatch if it ever happens again. There's also a writeup of this (and a few other projects on the path from initial client-side tinkering to full-on browser automation) on my website if you're interested in a 10000 word dive into the topic.(Some other recent experiments have included writing a demo track in Sonic Pi, and toying around w `osquery` to finally get some tangible exposure to SQL.)

description: RangerScience 45 days ago | prev | next [–]Relocate: Unlikely but let's talk!Resume/CV: https://www.linkedin.com/in/nick-barone-6919425Ehh ~15 years in startups, wearing lots of different hats, but mostly some flavor of full stack web developer, including devops and data engineering. I've also done some management (although I'm aiming for the "Staff Engineer" track), customer-facing engineering ("solution architect"), and a wee bit of embedded / on-device work. I pick up new stuff pretty quickly when there's a problem in front of me, and I'm that rare extrovert engineer, so bring on the social parts of the job!My career has two pillars: internal engineering, and customer-facing engineering. When I'm doing customer-facing stuff (B2B), I'm deploying the company's technology to solve the client's problems.For the last few jobs, my bosses have been telling me I'm ready to be a CTO, so if you're looking for a technical cofounder... let's chat!PS - my Rubyconf 2023 lightning talk: https://youtu.be/tNcfYLuQ5Es?t=4265 and my Rubyconf 2021 talk: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JgWAWwF6pNYPPS - If you're making some science fiction into something real, I definitely want to talk to you.

description: pickledish 44 days ago | prev | next [–]---Hi! My name is Brandon.I'm a backend and platform dev with a little over 5 years of experience, most recently as an SRE at Datadog for about 3 years before I left (of my own volition, wanted a little break). I have a bunch of experience with API severs and data pipelines, not only designing and writing code for the services themselves, but also setting up and monitoring the infra it runs on. I've built each of these kinds of systems before from scratch, both alone and leading small groups, and I really enjoy it -- I have more specifics on my resume.(or, check out Cloudy But No Rain (https://www.cbnr.xyz, working title will probably change soon) — it's open source, made up of a few Go services and OSS deployments, and I run it myself on bare-metal k8s.)My ideal job would be someplace small, product-oriented, and sustainable (in both a financial and human sense, so think less VC-powered rocket ships and more bootstraps, nonprofits, b-corps and co-ops). Of course, if you're not 100% of those things but think we might be a good fit anyway, please do still reach out!And finally (thanks a bunch if you’re reading all this), I think my biggest strength is that I give a crap. Always, about everything — I make time to write great documentation, I jump in to help in other people’s incidents, I create a deluge of comments when someone sends me a doc for feedback. I find a lot of joy in doing good work and I believe that’s why people often seem to really enjoy having me on their team.If you want to work with someone like that, I’d love to see an email from you. Thanks!

description: dijit 45 days ago | prev | next [–]Relocate:  Yes.I'm Jan, I've been CTO for 18 or so months now and I've been doing a pretty good job or so I'm told. Prior to this job I was SRE, focused primarily with always online AAA games. I'm well regarded for my trustworthiness, transparency and integrity. I have a fatal flaw though which is that I am not very good in low-trust environments. I have a strong passion which has stayed with me for 15 years. I will do anything for any price as long as I can take pride in the products.Examples of products that I would be proud to work on would be; GCP (ha!), Mullvad, Tailscale, AAA games (not gambling) and developer tooling (I have a deep passion for this because I like to help people).I'd like to go back to SRE, or if I am a manager I would like to be hands on, the human element is something I seem to be good at as long as I can take responsibility but that's not something most companies would permit me to do outside of the C-Level and it has been 18 months of 14h days (even weekends) and no vacation. So I'm ready to leave that behind for those reasons.

technologies: Embedded systems, automotive, machine learning, signal processing, data science, real time computing, safety processes (MISRA, ISO26262, etc), MATLAB, FPGA.
description: wcunning 46 days ago | prev | next [–]Background: Masters in control theory and signal processing, working in the auto industry for the last 7 years, first on low level powertrain software then the last year or so on LIDAR/computer vision for autonomous vehicles. I've done the most work in C, but I'm now getting up to speed on python and the computer vision/numpy/data processing pipeline stack there for data quality/perception work, along with Linux desktop application architecting and development for AV utilities. Recently had to read the Linux kernel source and use the BCC tool suite to find a subtle issue in the network stack causing high latency on sensor data for AV, also coincidentally fixed most of the network timing infrastructure.Currently doing full stack development on internal data collection and analysis tools, including new tooling for low level embedded system debugging in autonomous vehicles.Primary skills include hard real time embedded systems, safety critical applications, firmware development, system integration and complex hardware/software interaction debugging, along with detailed data analysis problems.Side interests include machining, 3D printing, embedded system development, coffee roasting and furniture making.

description: codeforafrica 45 days ago | prev | next [–]Contract, part-time employmentContact: Email: see profile or http://codingforafrica.at/Like this Ask HN: Recommend employers with positive social impact [https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=31518945], I am looking for similar work. I am a European software developer who has lived and worked on four continents. Now it's time to move on and so i am in the process to relocate to Africa.While i could find a job elsewhere i believe that the experience living in an area where my work is going to have an impact gives me a better understanding of the needs of the location i am serving. Whether it is through direct contact with clients and users or just by being part of a local community and learning about the reality of living there.I have more than a decade of experience running a company, doing software development, support and training and mentoring adults and students, as well as working on educational projects, and i am willing to take on a mixture of roles as needed to support a project.I am also open to work for a company anywhere as long as the work can be done fully remote from Africa.In addition, i want to use part of my income to hire local interns and junior developers and train them in order to pass on my experience. If you want to support this, i would love to work with you. Also if you are interested in hiring African developers yourself.

technologies: Front-end web, JS, TS, CSS, Svelte, React, React Native
description: tobr 76 days ago | prev | next [–]Designer/developer with about 15 years experience making things for the web and beyond. I've had titles like design technologist, interaction designer, front-end developer and UX designer, working for design agencies and product startups. Reach out for CV and portfolio.I'd love to find a product team who are solving design problems with code, and who see that good user experience is not a layer at the top of the stack, but something that is equally concerned with decisions below the surface. (Although I very much do care about that surface level polish too, such as interactivity, typography, copy, visual hierarchy and clear affordances)For complex design problems, I like to look for the smallest set of primitives or basic rules that can support user needs and desired outcomes, and try to build the design "bottom-up" from those. This tends to lead to elegant solutions with fewer edge cases and exceptions, and hold up better when having to adapt to previously unknown needs. If you are working on something interesting that fits this description, and need a designer who feels more at home in code than in Figma, please get in touch!

Whether it is through direct contact with clients and users or just by being part of a local community and learning about the reality of living there.I have more than a decade of experience running a company, doing software development, support and training and mentoring adults and students, as well as working on educational projects, and i am willing to take on a mixture of roles as needed to support a project.I am also open to work for a company anywhere as long as the work can be done fully remote from Africa.In addition, i want to use part of my income to hire local interns and junior developers and train them in order to pass on my experience. If you want to support this, i would love to work with you. Also if you are interested in hiring African developers yourself.

description: packetlost 75 days ago | prev | next [–]Currently technical lead for control systems of a flagship product at a quantum focused company. I work regularly with PhD physicists, electrical engineers, and lead a small team of software engineers to design, develop, and test both realtime and non-realtime control systems in a mix of constrained and unconstrained execution environments. I prefer to stay closer to the hardware, but above a kernel, and ideally on a network. Mostly work with Rust and Python these days, with Scheme on the side, but I can learn any toolchain quickly. I can even hack stuff together in the browser, but it won't be pretty. As you may probably guess, I have deep experience with scientific and distributed computing and networking.I'm not actively looking, but for the right opportunity I'll hear you out.

I think I would fit well as a founding engineer or product manager. Generally speaking, since I was 12 years old (now 37) I was always entrepreneurial. I’m fast in developing a prototype and in go to market.Cheers Jürgen

technologies: I find this a weird question. description: pickledish 75 days ago | prev | next [–]---Hi!My name is Brandon.I'm a backend and platform dev with a little over 5 years of experience, most recently as an SRE at Datadog for about 3 years before I quit. If you want to see for yourself the kind of things I’m good at, check out Cloudy But No Rain (https://www.cbnr.xyz, working title will probably change soon) — I built the whole thing from scratch and run it myself on bare-metal k8s.Here’s what I’m looking for in a job:* Small company (no more than ~25 developers) — I love knowing everyone I work with on a personal level.* Financially sustainable — this means “at least profitable”, even better are bootstraps, nonprofits, and co-ops!* Product oriented — my favorite work is when folks get together to iterate on something people love to use.And finally (thanks a bunch if you’re reading all this), I think my biggest strength is that I give a shit. Always, about everything — I make time to write great documentation, I jump in to help in other people’s incidents, I create a deluge of comments when someone sends me a doc for feedback. I find a lot of joy in doing good work and I believe that’s why people often seem to really enjoy having me on their team.If you want to work with someone like that, I’d love to see an email from you. Thanks!

description: flostk 3 months ago | next [–]Website: https://florianstecker.netI'm a postdoctoral mathematics researcher and professor at Florida State University. I'm looking to leave academia for a job in software engineering, machine learning, data science, or anything where my math skills can be useful.I have a broad knowledge of math, physics and computer science. I've been programming for most of my life, and regularly use computer experiments in my math work (see examples on my website). These tend to be niche problems, so I often build all algorithms from scratch. I have also worked in the industry a bit before my PhD (building simulation software in C++ and C#).As a mathematician, I am used to tackling hard problems without established solutions. I enjoy learning new things, and through years of teaching and presenting my research I am also fairly good at communicating complex ideas.I'm particularly interested in work which has an interesting algorithms or optimization aspect, like high-performance computing, compilers, low-level/embedded programming etc. I also got really interested in machine learning recently, and started reading about and experimenting with it (my math background helps here!). But I'm pretty open-minded, so if you think I could be useful for whatever you're doing, please reach out!

The frontend is a mix of vanilla JS and OCaml (using js_of_ocaml).My experience at startups has helped me learn how to build systems, and how to keep them running, simply and with minimal resources. (For example, as of this writing, Checkmate Champ has been running for 476 days without my intervention.) I also have extensive knowledge of algorithms; in graduate school, I was a teaching assistant for five years, mainly for the algorithms classes.I have learned a lot of languages over the years that I never got the chance to use in a professional setting, including Lisp, OCaml, Haskell, and Smalltalk. If you are using one of these, I would especially like to hear from you.

description: biribacdo 3 months ago | prev | next [–]Github: https://github.com/cabecadaLinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/vijaykumarjain/Hi, I am database reliability engineer who works on all aspects of keeping the databases (100s of them) up and running. I have used configuration management tools like puppet to deploy complex postgresql architectures and have experience with databases as big as 60TB and shards, backup of those shards, upgrades etc.I had a good reputation on not leaving any incident open which arise due to sudden bump in traffic, bugs, system issues etc and ensured minimum or no involvement of app developers in issue resolutions. I help answer queries on postgresql slack and citus slack (basic only). I have experience working in all the timezones in the world across my 14+ years, but for this role I would want to sleep at night unless its an oncall/incident. I have exposure to on prem systems/ bare metals, self managed virtualisation and microservices but using mesos/docker and AWS using theforeman. I have tutorial awareness of AWS and Kubernetes and Ansible, but I read a lot of code and have history of understanding most of the relevant infra stack in a couple of months without any hand holding. If you have read till here, Thank You for listening. I am passionate about postgresql and troubleshooting incidents to root causes.

description: wusticality 3 months ago | prev | next [–]Languages: Rust, Golang, C#, C++, Clojure, LuaBackend technologies: AWS, Kubernetes, Postgres, Docker, New Relic, .. the usual suspectsExpertise: Distributed systems, horizontal scalability, parallel programming, performance optimizationLinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/wusticalityI spent the first 15 years of my career building game engines for a living. During that period I've done it all, from streaming, networking, game object models, shaders, simluations, .. you name it. It left me with a knack for good design, optimization, parallel programming, and cpu / memory-awareness. My claim to fame is single-handedly building the game NinJump on iOS / Android back in the early days of mobile gaming. It had over 150 million downloads and hit #1 on iOS.Several years ago I transitioned to distributed computing, focusing on horizontal scalability. The past few years I've been working mostly in AWS, Golang, and Kubernetes. I've enjoyed the challenge of this transition. I didn't list all my engine cred above as I'm more focused on backend work these days.Finally, I'm a huge proponent of Rust. I rarely get attached to technology but working in Rust is just a joy. I'm always on the lookout for kickass Rust gigs, especially when they're not crypto-facing.Just freed up and fielding calls with folks. Cool opportunities welcome! :)

relocate: yes, to any location in Africa, where i can get the necessary permission to live and work.
technologies: Linux, Fullstack, System Administration.
resume: on request (software development, CTO, mentoring, training, fluent in English and German)
description: codeforafrica 3 months ago | prev | next [–]Contract, part-time employmentLike this Ask HN: Recommend employers with positive social impact [https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=31518945], I am looking for similar work. I am a European software developer who has lived and worked on four continents. Now it's time to move on and so i am in the process to relocate to Africa.While i could find a job elsewhere i believe that the experience living in an area where my work is going to have an impact gives me a better understanding of the needs of the location i am serving. Whether it is through direct contact with clients and users or just by being part of a local community and learning about the reality of living there.I have more than a decade of experience running a company, doing software development, support and training and mentoring adults and students, as well as working on educational projects, and i am willing to take on a mixture of roles as needed to support a project.I am also open to work for a company anywhere as long as the work can be done fully remote from Africa.In addition, my plan is to use part of my income to hire local interns and junior developers and train them in order to pass on my experience. If you want to support this, i would love to work with you. Also if you are interested in hiring African developers yourself.

remote: Yes. The last 5 years have been "remote only". I'm more productive WFH and will not consider having to buy a car I don't normally need and go back to wasting my time commuting.

technologies: I'm not limited by language, frameworks, or clouds, as I helped build several of them for current "bigtech" companies and can ramp up quickly due to my prior experience in contacting and consulting. From improving legacy infra and processes in an established telco company to scaling a fast-moving startup from 200K to 2M users. In my free time, I love writing Code That Is Poetry but day-to-day I am not an idealist engineer who doesn't compromise. Well-engineered code is clean and correct but correct above all else.Oh, also, I'm great at writing documentation. I consider myself introverted but apparently my communication skills are above average for Software Engineers. I also pride myself on my humility and modesty.I'd love to explore other technical positions in the games industry short of joining a AAA studio because (a) I don't want to crunch and (b) my skill set does not lay that way; other tech-creative industries would also appeal to me! Another particular interest is in B2C businesses where the 'C' is software developers. I'd love to chat and network about opportunities; if you think you have a product that could benefit from my skill set, drop me a line!

description: lewisgodowski 3 months ago | prev | next [–]Hello! I'm Lewis Godowski, a creatively-driven lead engineer with over a decade of experience across the Apple ecosystem. Passionate about the little details of good design and a strong advocate for the human-centered design process.Most recently, I was brought onto a new strategic business unit build to turnaround, manage, and lead an underperforming team of ~10 iOS engineers at a top 3 global motorcycle manufacturer. I had two main responsibilities I needed to balance: doing some heavy lifting as an individual contributor, and more importantly people management (upwards with product stakeholders, laterally with other pods and work streams, and downwards with my team). I identified and reduced inefficiencies in our scrum sprint cycle rituals, and established a standard architecture, code style guide, and best practices document for the client's codebase, resulting in a 28% increase in velocity and allowing us to deliver on schedule for an in-person launch event with 150+ dealerships.Unfortunately, my current role has been transforming more and more into a business/digital consultant, which means a lot of my time is spent working on slide decks and high-level architectures that never see the light of day. It's bumming me out and taking me away from what I really enjoy: writing code, learning new skills, and wearing multiple hats to solve problems.Ideally, I'm looking for an iOS (or Vapor, a server-side Swift framework) role as either manager or IC that lets me really flex my Swift and iOS expertise.

description: The_Fox 3 months ago | prev | next [–]13 years of experience in startup software development and DevOps across web apps, cloud, and Linux networking. Six years of leadership in teams of up to 7 people.Looking for an engineering manager or senior IC position to mentor your team and make something people want.Here are a sample of things I've accomplished:* I built a platform for hosting web applications using Kubernetes at a major cloud provider and taught engineers to operate and improve it. It uses Helm to manage the instances of the single-tenant app and includes a Python application to manage the customer instances based on configuration from the subscription management vendor.* I trained and mentored a team of developers in software patterns, communication, and prioritizing work, and I reduced context switching in the team’s workflows, leading to a 72% increase in velocity in two months.* I maintain the community Apt package for Helm, the Kubernetes package manager, which is downloaded more than 200,000 times per month.* I improved performance of a proprietary VPN by adopting Cython, permitting use of C functions in Python, resulting in a 2.5x increase in network throughput when limited by CPU* I created a system to control calls in Asterisk with AI-trained voice commands ("hey asterisk, dial extension 1") https://github.com/mattfox/asterisk-voice-control* In progress- I'm managing a project for getting a B2B SaaS company a SOC 2 Type II report

description: robbs 4 months ago | prev | next [–]I’m a Full Stack Software Engineer with 13+ years of experience.I love to learn and share what I know! As a full stack Python developer at a cinema VFX company, I brought React to my team and set them up with a toolkit that enable them to build apps 4x faster. I ran workshops, mentored 1:1 and developed best practices to clarify to my team how to build with Python and React. At a national Internet company, I solved browser breaking artifacts on the national Broadband Map using Python and PostGIS. At a Solar SaaS, I used Python to abstract bespoke Solar Lender APIs so that the Sales Platform could onboard new lenders with minimal changes, ultimately leading to gigawatts of panels on roofs and billions of dollars of deals done. Recently, I've maintained a legacy Django platform while executing a migration into a new platform.I'm proud that my Python and React has helped create movies with box offices in the billions, helped an entire country find broadband and installed gigawatts of clean energy. I'm excited to leverage my Python and React skills to contribute to your team's success.

I have undertaken large group projects like creating full-stack applications with Django and Next.js, API usage like Discord.py, many Google APIs, and the use of AI through ChatGPT. description: Niksko 4 months ago | prev | next [–]Typescript, Golang, AWS, TerraformHi, I'm an engineer with 7 years of experience looking for a new challenge. I've spent a lot of time in the Kubernetes space and am very comfortable with Kubernetes and adjacent tech (Istio, ArgoCD, Helm, Prometheus/Grafana), but I'm also a strong software engineer (TypeScript, Golang, Python). I've also done some work lately as a technical product manager on internal developer platforms. I'm a great writer and communicator, and I can lead and organize multiple teams toward a technical or non-technical goal.I'm open to a variety of work. I'm a quick learner and love picking up new tech, so as long as you're ok with giving me some gentle guidance on idioms and libraries I'm confident I can pick up whatever tech stack you need me to work on. I'm naturally very curious, and if you're working in an interesting industry with a great product that doesn't exploit its users, I'm eager to build something great with you. Above all, I'm looking for a company that has a strong purpose and values that match my own.A note on remote: this is a hard requirement for me. The only exception might be a 'synchronized hybrid' where everyone is in the office on the same day(s), but that seems rare and you'd also need an office in Vancouver.

description: mtoohig 4 months ago | prev | next [–]I am US citizen returning to US by the end of the year. I have worked the past 8 years the country of Vanuatu as a solo-software engineer while I waited for my wife to obtain her US visa and then covid kept us in Vanuatu longer than expected. I've built a variety of systems from a Netflix clone for a local ISP including in-house transcoding pipelines (internet too expensive/bandwidth too limited for customers to access real Netflix), a linear TV channel for a local TV broadcaster with automatic playlist building/solving, a booking system for international tourism to Vanuatu, a Foursquare-esque PWA for local businesses, a license plate detection and collection app, a logistics and assets management system for local freight company and many other web scrapers and other projects for fun.As a result, I've had a well rounded background of experience, worked with a lot of on-premise hardware, various technologies and was responsible for everything top to bottom which means to say finding clients, investigating requirements, design and implementation and deployment was on me.I'm hoping to find a rewarding and challenging project to work on in the States and to join a team of like minded software engineers. I also like kava.

description: piotr-yuxuan 4 months ago | prev | next [–]GitHub: https://github.com/piotr-yuxuanMy dream position:- Business impact: always a business case to improve things with lower latency, higher availability, better scalability, lower operational costs. What some businesses really need is just a static webpage in Cloudfront: I want more.- Corporate structure: a result-driven company that welcomes innovation. I'm happy with either large enterprises that move slowly or small nimble start-up, each has different strengths :-)- Technical mindset: bottom-up tech design, right tool for the right job. Client-oriented design. Revenue-oriented & business-focused, it should matter from day 0. No abstraction is better than bad abstraction. Let free patterns emerge from organic growth.- Technical landscape: data-intensive systems that can be relied upon, with strong business-relevant needs for performance, reliability, durability, and resilience.- Team dynamics: engineers have and share areas of responsibility. No echo chamber or ivory-tower architect. All of us are collectively accountable for systems maintenance and architecture.

I’m at my best working with people who are optimistic and driven, where everyone’s all about teamwork and helping each other grow.

I've built integrations with various observability platforms, and created internal tools where integrations weren't an option.In these positions I've set up CI/CD platforms, designed numerous webs systems that were fully documented using infrastructure as code tools, integrated notification and observability platforms, regularly preformed PR reviews, pushed to establish better engineer practices (automated formatting, static typing, dependency management, coding style, etc), and have lead teams of other engineers on many projects.I'm currently consulting on a few short term contracts and am looking to take on long term employment for an interesting project.

description: piotr-yuxuan 5 months ago | prev | next [–]GitHub: https://github.com/piotr-yuxuanMy dream position:- Business impact: always a business case to improve things with lower latency, higher availability, better scalability, lower operational costs. What some businesses really need is just a static webpage in Cloudfront: I want more.- Corporate structure: a result-driven company that welcomes innovation. I'm happy with either large enterprises that move slowly or small nimble start-up, each has different strengths :-)- Technical mindset: bottom-up tech design, right tool for the right job. Client-oriented design. Revenue-oriented & business-focused, it should matter from day 0. No abstraction is better than bad abstraction. Let free patterns emerge from organic growth.- Technical landscape: data-intensive systems that can be relied upon, with strong business-relevant needs for performance, reliability, durability, and resilience.- Team dynamics: engineers have and share areas of responsibility. No echo chamber or ivory-tower architect. All of us are collectively accountable for systems maintenance and architecture.

I’ve been doing iOS development for 6+ years and web development (mainly frontend with some backend) for 4+ years. - I’ve worked on various web and iOS projects both as a full-time dev & as a freelancer or independent developer - I’ve built online and mobile games, worked on an e-commerce website and a voice based digital assistant, developed a web based AI chat app, built many portfolio sites & landing pages - My main expertise is in frontend dev (web + iOS) but I built quite a few backends too for some freelance & personal projects - I love to build things from scratch and make the critical architectural decisions for a new project & quickly bring a new idea to life - I also love the challenge of joining a large project and having to figure out how everything works as quickly as I can. I can take any project that I have the skills for but I’d love to work on something AI & LLM related.

technologies: UNIX, AWS, Python, Erlang, Perl, MacOS, SQL, NoSQL, C, Java
description: macintux 5 months ago | prev | next [–]I have spent my career straddling the line between infrastructure management and software development. I've worked for a Fortune 200 company and been the first technical hire at a startup.I've touched far more technologies than I could reasonably list here (or even remember), but my primary strength isn't any of them: it's being able to step into a role, work with stakeholders to understand the business priorities, find the gaps in the current coverage, and make the world a little more robust.I've masqueraded as a technical writer (see discussion of one of my favorite blog posts at https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=6722408 — all of my Basho posts are archived at https://web.archive.org/web/20170801133203/http://basho.com/...), presented at conferences about NoSQL data modeling, Apple MDM, Erlang, immutability, and logical time (but not concurrently), jumped in to help my employer with a NLP project in my evenings and weekends, created a WebSphere deployment DSL, trained co-workers on TCP/IP and UNIX, and written kernel software (but not for, admittedly, a very long time).(At Basho I started copy-editing their marketing materials while still in the hiring process; that was a lesson in keeping my head down, but fortunately they hired me anyway.)Let me make your life a little bit easier.

llmsolutions 6 months ago | prev | next [–]I provide consulting services for everything in the OpenAI / LLM / ChatGPT realm. I'm an ex-Google consultant who now enjoys working with LLMs. After extensive work on projects for the likes of Village Global, I've developed advanced techniques for solving traditional problems in the space. A typical basic chat bot / question answering system is $15,000 flat fee (excluding cloud hosting and OpenAI API costs) with a 2-week turnaround.

technologies: Full Stack, C# (mainly), .NET Core, Web API , EF/SQL, Azure, a little AWS, TS/JS, React, CI/CD...
description: mrwizrd 6 months ago | prev | next [–]Hey everyone :) First time posting in one of these threads.I've been at my current company since 2021, and was promoted to lead my team last year. I've really enjoyed supporting them and passing my values on, but the time has come to look at moving as the company itself has grown and changed.Over about 10 years working mostly in the Microsoft stack, I've architected, built or contributed to a variety of business applications - if not at a "product" company, the usual consultancy fun of taking a spec the size of a postage stamp, working out what the solution looks like, and then building it. I'm equally happy being a one-man-band or working in a team.Github: https://www.github.com/adamjamesAt home, I've built up a small collection of projects and services depending on need and interest - TrueNAS, an OpenWRT-flashed router for network-wide adblock, and a small troupe of Raspberry Pi's with RTL-SDR for decoding ADS-B. I'm currently mucking with earthly.dev to automate building Arch Linux ARM images and sniffing the traffic from our home SMART meter.I'm physically disabled, so remote or one day a week onsite is critical, but occasional travel with plenty of notice is fine. I'm looking to work with/for someone who values people over KPI's. Ideally your incentives are aligned with building the best product/service possible for the end user and we're doing some good for the world. If you want someone to come in and invest time and effort improving developer quality of life, I also love finding and fixing little annoyances.

description: awayto 6 months ago | prev | next [–]My name is Joe. I am a software engineer. I build my own software, Awayto, which you can currently demo at https://awayto.store to see my output. The demo features a communications platform, similar to what you would expect if you were running an online writing center. There is RBAC, scheduling & online appointments, voice/video calling, shared whiteboard/document marking, and more. However, the system is built in a generic fashion where features can be added or removed on a whim, leading to a pivotable system for whatever business you're creating.I'm interested in working with businesses with the above feature set interests, educational groups, community services, and so on. The software is fully open source and runs bare metal or (currently) on hetzner. As a freelancer I am looking for work on projects of similar scope, as well as implement Awayto for your own purposes, should you need.I've been developing for 25 years and am of course open to other projects as well. And I look forward to hearing what ideas you have, and your needs.Please contact me at joe \at\ keybittech.com for any inquiries, and check my profile for more info and links to my work.

I am an excellent person to work with because I love talking about anything under the sun, and I maintain a lot of interests outside my field of occupation. I have a fair bit of experience with Data Science and ML, and did a variety of work in the field – Data Science for Public Good, internships at an M&E firm (Arqaam) and for an F&B flavor prediction company (Gastrograph AFS). At DSPG, I also build dashboards to portray the analyses we did. I believe my strongest skillset is my ability to look at numbers and patterns and be excited to unearth whatever I can with them. I am an excellent person to work with because I love talking about anything under the sun, and I maintain a lot of interests outside my field of occupation. I am also a home Barista and enjoy discussing coffee brewing – always happy to make a cup for you and tell you all about it!

description: piotr-yuxuan 6 months ago | prev | next [–]GitHub: https://github.com/piotr-yuxuanMy dream position:- Business impact: always a business case to improve things with lower latency, higher availability, better scalability, lower operational costs. What some businesses really need is just a static webpage in Cloudfront: I want more.- Corporate structure: a result-driven company that welcomes innovation.- Technical mindset: bottom-up tech design, right tool for the right job. Client-oriented design. Revenue-oriented, it should matter from day 0. No abstraction is better than bad abstraction. Let free patterns emerge from organic growth.- Technical landscape: data-intensive systems that can be relied upon, with strong business-relevant needs for performance, reliability, durability, and resilience.- Team dynamics: engineers have and share areas of responsibility. No echo chamber or ivory-tower architect. We should all be collectively accountable for systems architecture.

Turns out that all popular architectures are just instances of a more general approach. Infinite transformer window is possible. Attention is just a particular case of Hopf convolution. Verification is possible. Faster training, faster inference. Possibly interpretability. But it goes beyond transformers.The machine learning process is analogous to renormalization from QFT which in retrospect makes sense.I have recently written a paper on this https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01834 however a lot has changed since then.I'm in the process of implementing a framework that implements these ideas.I'm looking for ML R&D position with a company that appreciates this approach.Contact me to learn more.I have a discord channel https://discord.cofunctional.ai.LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/adam-nemecek-b40153104/Education: CS from Harvard

technologies: Docker, Python, C, Go, Embedded Linux
description: jordemort 6 months ago | prev | next [–]Here are some of things I have done for my previous employers, that I could be doing for you:- Put all your services in containers, and make it easy to spin up development environments that resemble your production environment- Package your SaaS into a virtual machine image that customers can self-host, and publish versions of it for all the major clouds and hypervisors- Create Linux-based firmware for your embedded device, and work with the folks at the factory to get it flashed on the production line- Reverse-engineer that weird binary that came in your board's BSP, and tell you exactly what it is doing and how to replicate it- Write clever blog posts and technical articles about your products, which will explain how to use them while also being fun to read- Lead a team of engineers, help them grow in their roles, and ship thingsI love startups and greatly prefer them over working at a big company. I only work remotely, and I prefer to work for remote-first companies; I'm happy to meet up in person a few times a year, though. I'm a GitHub alumnus (from back before the acquisition) and have been a guest author for Linux Weekly News. I have an M.S. in Computer Science and over twenty years of industry experience. description: jordemort 6 months ago | prev | next [–]Here are some of things I have done for my previous employers, that I could be doing for you:- Put all your services in containers, and make it easy to spin up development environments that resemble your production environment- Package your SaaS into a virtual machine image that customers can self-host, and publish versions of it for all the major clouds and hypervisors- Create Linux-based firmware for your embedded device, and work with the folks at the factory to get it flashed on the production line- Reverse-engineer that weird binary that came in your board's BSP, and tell you exactly what it is doing and how to replicate it- Write clever blog posts and technical articles about your products, which will explain how to use them while also being fun to read- Lead a team of engineers, help them grow in their roles, and ship thingsI love startups and greatly prefer them over working at a big company. I only work remotely, and I prefer to work for remote-first companies; I'm happy to meet up in person a few times a year, though. I'm a GitHub alumnus (from back before the acquisition) and have been a guest author for Linux Weekly News. I have an M.S. in Computer Science and over twenty years of industry experience. I live in the US Midwest, so I might be cheaper than you're expecting!

description: jborden13 6 months ago | prev | next [–]Hey HN, I've been working on Spence, a Generative HR tool I believe can change the job seeking game for many. Here's the lowdown:https://www.kindbuds.ai/ght/spence* Input: Provide Spence with your current resume.* Target: Share a job listing you're interested in.* Output: Spence analyzes the job description, then refines your resume and crafts a cover letter, making sure both align closely with the job's requirements.The main idea? Too many resumes get lost in automated systems or aren't tailored enough for the specific job. Spence helps bridge that gap by ensuring your documents are as relevant as possible to the position you're applying for.Keen to hear your feedback, and if anyone's up for testing, I'm all ears. I'm also for hire.

I'd love to chat and network about opportunities; if you think you have a product that could benefit from my skill set, drop me a line!

description: lewisgodowski 6 months ago | prev | next [–]Hello! I'm Lewis Godowski, a software engineer with ~10 years of experience across iOS and backend. I find joy in dogs, desserts, and the small details of good design. I am a strong advocate for end users and their experience with a product.Most recently, I was brought onto a new strategic business unit build to turnaround, manage, and lead an underperforming team of ~10 iOS engineers at a top 10 global motorcycle manufacturer. I had two main responsibilities I needed to balance: people management (upwards with product stakeholders, laterally with other pods and work streams, and downwards with my team) and doing some heavy lifting as an individual contributor. I created structure and improved hygiene in the team, codebase, and sprint/scrum life cycle, which stabilized our velocity and allowed us to find our rhythm and deliver on schedule.Unfortunately, my current role has been transforming more and more into a business/digital consultant, which means a lot of working on slide decks and high-level architectures that never see the light of day. It's bumming me out and taking me away from what I really enjoy: writing code, learning new skills, and wearing multiple hats to solve problems.Ideally, I'm looking for an iOS (or Vapor, a server-side Swift framework) role that lets me really flex my Swift expertise.
